content: SHORT TITLE; FINDINGS. The "Cost of Higher Education Review Act of 1997" acknowledges the significant increase in tuition at public colleges and universities compared to household income and consumer goods costs. A 1995 survey highlighted concerns about college affordability among freshmen. In 1994-1995, median household income increased by 82%, while the Consumer Price Index rose by 74%. A 1995 survey of college freshmen showed high concern about college affordability, making it one of the most expensive investments for American families. Establishment of National Commission on the Cost of Higher Education, known as the "Commission", with defined membership. The Commission, established for the Cost of Higher Education, consists of 7 members appointed by various leaders and the Secretary of Education, each with expertise. The Commission for the Cost of Higher Education consists of 7 members appointed by different leaders and the Secretary of Education, each with expertise in higher education finance, Federal financial aid programs, education economics research, higher education administration, or business efficiency and cost reduction programs. The Commission for the Cost of Higher Education consists of 7 members with expertise in higher education finance, Federal financial aid programs, education economics research, higher education administration, or business efficiency and cost reduction programs. The members elect a Chairman and Vice Chairperson, with a majority required for a quorum. All appointments are made by different leaders and the Secretary of Education. The Commission for the Cost of Higher Education elects a Chairman and Vice Chairperson. A majority of members constitute a quorum. Appointments must be made within 30 days. The Chairman of the Committee on Education may act for the Speaker if needed. Appointments to the Commission for the Cost of Higher Education must be made within 30 days. If an appointment is not made within that time, the Chairman of the Committee on Education and the Workforce may act for the Speaker of the House of Representatives. Each member of the Commission for the Cost of Higher Education is entitled to one vote. The Speaker of the House of Representatives, Minority Leader of the House of Representatives, Majority Leader of the Senate, and Minority Leader of the Senate can appoint representatives to act on their behalf. Each member of the Commission is entitled to one vote, which is equal to every other member's vote. Vacancies do not affect the Commission's powers and are filled as per the original appointment method. Members receive no additional pay or benefits. Members of the Commission are entitled to one vote each, vacancies do not affect the Commission's powers and are filled as per the original appointment method. Members do not receive additional pay or benefits. Members of the Commission do not receive extra pay or benefits. Private citizens may get travel expenses for Commission service. The initial meeting must happen within 40 days of the Act's enactment. SEC. 4. FUNCTIONS OF COMMISSION. The Commission will study and provide specific recommendations on the increase in tuition, methods to reduce tuition, trends in administrative costs, faculty workload, and remuneration. The Commission will study trends in administrative costs, faculty workload, remuneration, faculty-to-student ratios, and construction/renovation of collegiate facilities. The Commission will also examine trends in adjunct faculty usage, faculty-to-student ratios, classroom hours, tenure practices, construction/renovation of facilities, modernization for new technologies, and the impact on tuition. Additionally, they will analyze the effects of institutional financial aid and tuition discounting on tuition increases. The Commission will investigate the impact of institutional financial aid and tuition discounting on tuition increases, including aid demographics and the use of Federal financial aid to offset costs. The Commission will examine the impact of institutional financial aid and tuition discounting on tuition increases, including aid demographics and the use of Federal financial aid to offset costs. Recommendations will be made on reducing mandates contributing to tuition increases and establishing a mechanism for timely distribution of data on tuition trends and operating costs of colleges and universities. The Commission will investigate the impact of laws, regulations, and mandates on tuition increases, recommend ways to reduce these mandates, establish a mechanism for timely data distribution on tuition trends, assess the role of student financial aid programs in tuition hikes, and address other relevant topics. The Commission will submit a final report to the President and Congress within 120 days of its first meeting, detailing findings, conclusions, and recommendations on the impact of laws, regulations, and mandates on tuition increases, student financial aid programs, and other related topics. The Commission will submit a report to the President and Congress within 120 days of its first meeting, containing findings, conclusions, and recommendations for administrative and legislative action. Recommendations require a majority vote from Commission members. The Commission has powers to submit a report with findings, conclusions, and recommendations to the President and Congress within 120 days of its first meeting. Recommendations need a majority vote from Commission members. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, adopt rules and regulations, and request information from federal agencies for the purpose of carrying out the Act. The Commission may request information from Federal agencies for the purpose of the Act, and agencies must provide such information upon request. Federal agencies must provide information to the Commission upon request, as required by the Freedom of Information Act. The head of any agency may also make facilities and services available to the Commission upon request. The head of any Federal agency must make facilities and services available to the Commission upon request, and may detail personnel to assist the Commission on a nonreimbursable basis. The Commission is also allowed to use the United States mails. The Commission may use the United States mails and enter into contracts with various entities for research purposes. Personnel can be detailed to assist the Commission on a nonreimbursable basis. The Commission can enter into contracts for research purposes with State agencies, private firms, institutions, and individuals. The Chairperson has the power to appoint and fix compensation for staff members. The Chairperson of the Commission has the power to appoint, terminate, and fix compensation for staff members without following certain regulations and provisions. The Chairperson of the Commission can appoint an Executive Director and additional staff without following certain regulations, at rates not exceeding the maximum rate for level IV of the Executive Schedule. The Commission is authorized to appropriate up to $650,000 for expenses and these funds can remain available until expended or one year after the Commission's termination. The Commission will cease to exist 60 days after submitting its final report as required by section 4(b).
